structured_data.name: Temperature and precipitation gridded data for global and regional domains derived from in-situ and satellite observations
structured_data.description: This dataset provides high-resolution gridded temperature and precipitation observations from a selection of sources (GISTEMP, Berkeley Earth, CPC, CPC-CONUS, CHIRPS, IMERG, CMORPH, GPCC, CRU). It also contains daily global average near-surface temperature anomalies. All fields are defined on either daily or monthly frequency. The dataset is no longer supported by data providers and no expected updates.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Depends on the model: global, quasi-global, Africa and contiguous United States (CONUS). Horizontal resolution depends on the model: 0.1 x 0.1, 0.25 x 0.25, 0.2 x 0.2, 0.5 x 0.5, 1 x 1, 2.5 x 2.5 and Horizontal average.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Depends on the model; daily and monthly frequency.

structured_data.name: IPCC AR6 WGI Chapter 11 Figures
structured_data.data_format: PNG (for figures), implied scientific data formats (e.g., NetCDF, GeoTIFF) for underlying data
structured_data.description: This content provides access to figures from Chapter 11 of the IPCC AR6 Working Group I report. While the figures themselves are images, they represent underlying scientific data related to climate change, including potential heatwave indicators. The chapter authors are listed, indicating the scientific rigor of the source.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Global (implied by the IPCC report's scope)

structured_data.name: NOAA Monthly U.S. Climate Gridded Dataset (NClimGrid)
structured_data.method_of_access: Direct download (archive and real-time files), THREDDS Catalog, AWS S3 Explorer
structured_data.granularity: 5x5 lat/lon grid for the Continental United States, Alaska, and Hawaii
structured_data.description: The NOAA Monthly U.S. Climate Gridded Dataset (NClimGrid) consists of four climate variables derived from the GHCN-D dataset: maximum temperature, minimum temperature, average temperature and precipitation. Each file provides monthly values in a 5x5 lat/lon grid for the Continental United States. Data is available from 1895 to the present. In March 2015, new Alaska data was included in the nClimDiv dataset. In January 2025, the National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI) began summarizing the State of the Climate for Hawaii. NCEI maintains monthly statewide, divisional, and gridded average temperature, maximum temperatures (highs), minimum temperature (lows) and precipitation data for Hawaii over the period 1991-2025. The dataset is updated monthly.

structured_data.name: Global near real-time daily apparent temperature and heat wave dataset
structured_data.method_of_access: The content is a data article, implying the dataset is available, likely through the journal or associated data repositories. No direct download link or API is provided in the snippet.
structured_data.description: This dataset provides global near real-time daily apparent temperature and heat wave data. It is presented in a data article in the Geoscience Data Journal, authored by Cong Yin, Yaping Yang, Xiaona Chen, Xiafang Yue, Yangxiaoyue Liu, and Ying Xin from institutions including the Chinese Academy of Sciences.

structured_data.name: HadCRUT5, CRUTEM5, HadSST4 Temperature Datasets
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files (netCDF, text files) and links to Met Office/CEDA for more data files.
structured_data.description: HadCRUT is a global temperature dataset, providing gridded temperature anomalies across the world as well as averages for the hemispheres and the globe as a whole. CRUTEM and HadSST are temperature datasets for the land and ocean regions, respectively, and contribute to the global dataset. Developed by the Climatic Research Unit (University of East Anglia and NCAS) jointly with the Hadley Centre (UK Met Office). The latest version is HadCRUT5, formed using data from CRUTEM5 and HadSST4. All versions are being updated at one or two monthly intervals.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Since 1850 (HadCRUT5 Analysis), updated monthly/bi-monthly (e.g., 2025-02 end month, 2025-05-13 updated)

structured_data.name: CHIRTS-daily quasi-global high-resolution daily temperature data set
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable PDF, machine-accessible metadata file via DOI
structured_data.data_format: NetCDF (implied by typical climate data formats)
structured_data.description: CHIRTS-daily is a high-resolution daily temperature data set derived by merging monthly Climate Hazards center InfraRed Temperature with Stations climate record and daily temperatures from version 5 of the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts Re-Analysis (ERA5). It provides estimates of 2-meter air temperature and shows very good representation of heat wave trends.

structured_data.name: IPCC SR15 Chapter 3: Impacts of 1.5°C and 2°C of Warming
structured_data.description: This document discusses the impacts of global temperature increases, specifically focusing on the differences between 1.5°C and 2°C warming above pre-industrial levels. It highlights the reduced negative impacts on intensity and frequency of extreme events, resources, ecosystems, biodiversity, food security, cities, tourism, and carbon removal if warming is limited to 1.5°C. It also notes that an average warming of 1.5°C across the globe raises the risk of heatwaves and heavy rainfall events. The report is from the IPCC.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Pre-industrial to future projections (1.5°C and 2°C warming scenarios)

structured_data.name: GHCN_CAMS Gridded 2m Temperature (Land)
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files (NetCDF4), web interface for plotting/subsetting, Thredds Catalog
structured_data.description: GHCN_CAMS is a high resolution (0.5x0.5) analyzed global land surface temperatures from 1948 to near present, updated daily. It combines station observations from the Global Historical Climatology Network version 2 and the Climate Anomaly Monitoring System (GHCN + CAMS) and uses unique interpolation methods including an anomaly interpolation approach with spatially-temporally varying temperature lapse rates.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: 0.5 degree latitude x 0.5 degree longitude global grid (360x720), 89.75S - 89.75N, 0.25E - 359.75E.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Monthly means from 1948/01 to 2025/08; Long term monthly means using 1981-2010.

structured_data.name: Climate projections at a convection-permitting scale of extreme temperature indices for an archipelago with a complex microclimate structure
structured_data.description: This study applies a dynamic downscaling methodology using the WRF modeling system with a spatial resolution of 3 km to obtain projections of temperature extreme indices for an archipelago with complex orography (Canary Islands). The projections cover the periods 2030–2059 (MID) and 2070–2099 (END) for RCPs 4.5 and 8.5 scenarios. The study analyzes indices defined by ETCCDI, including TX, TN, DTR, TR, TX90P, TN10P, WSDI, and CSDI, and also return levels and periods for annual maximum temperature using GEV. Future changes are calculated against a modeled reference period of 1980–2009 (HIS).

structured_data.name: HadISDH.extremes Part II: Exploring Humid Heat Extremes Using Wet Bulb Temperature Indices
structured_data.description: This paper introduces the HadISDH.extremes global gridded monitoring product, which provides a range of wet and dry bulb temperature extremes indices. It quantifies exposure to humid versus dry heat events and explores 'stealth heat events' where humidity is high but temperature is moderate. The product covers the period 1973–2022, showing significant increases in humid extremes (TwX) and frequency of moderate humid extreme events (TwX90p) globally.

structured_data.name: Extreme heat, preterm birth, and stillbirth: A global analysis across 14 lower-middle income countries
structured_data.description: This study is the first global assessment of extreme heat events and adverse birth outcomes, specifically preterm birth and stillbirth, across 14 lower-middle income countries (LMICs). It links globally gridded meteorological data with spatially and temporally resolved Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data. The study found that higher maximum temperatures and smaller diurnal temperature range during the last week before birth increased the risk of preterm birth and stillbirth.

structured_data.name: TerraClimate, a high-resolution global dataset of monthly climate and climatic water balance from 1958–2015
structured_data.description: TerraClimate is a high-spatial resolution (1/24°, ~4-km) monthly climate and climatic water balance dataset for global terrestrial surfaces from 1958–2015. It combines high-spatial resolution climatological normals from WorldClim with coarser resolution time-varying data to produce monthly data for precipitation, maximum and minimum temperature, wind speed, vapor pressure, and solar radiation. It also produces monthly surface water balance datasets.

structured_data.name: CHIRTS-daily
structured_data.description: CHIRTS-daily is a quasi-global, high-resolution (0.05° x 0.05°, approx. 5km) data set of daily maximum and minimum temperatures, developed by Verdin, A., Funk, C., Peterson, P. et al. The data is available in SWAT format.

structured_data.name: Daily Global 5km Satellite Coral Bleaching Heat Stress Monitoring Products (Version 1.0)
structured_data.method_of_access: web interface query, archived data available for download
structured_data.description: NOAA Coral Reef Watch (CRW) provided near real-time global 50km-resolution satellite coral bleaching monitoring until April 30, 2020. These first-generation products served as a global early-warning system for coral reef ecosystem physical environmental changes. The Version 1.0 (v1.0) daily global 5km satellite coral bleaching heat stress monitoring product suite, released in June 2012, is a new-generation version based on NOAA/NESDIS 5km SST analysis. It includes sea surface temperature (SST), SST Anomaly, Coral Bleaching HotSpot, Degree Heating Week (DHW), and Bleaching Alert Area products. The 5km products offer improved data density and spatial and temporal resolutions compared to the heritage 50km products.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Daily (from June 2012 onwards for 5km products); 1997-2020 (for 50km heritage products)

structured_data.name: Global assessment of extreme heat events and adverse birth outcomes
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query, article abstract available
structured_data.description: This study is the first global assessment of extreme heat events and adverse birth outcomes, specifically preterm birth and stillbirth, building the evidence base for Lower- to Middle-Income Countries (LMICs). It links globally gridded meteorological data with spatially and temporally resolved Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data on adverse birth outcomes. The study found that higher maximum temperatures and smaller diurnal temperature range during the last week before birth increased the risk of preterm birth and stillbirth.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Globally gridded meteorological data, spatially and temporally resolved DHS data

structured_data.name: Changes in global heat waves and its socioeconomic exposure in a warmer future
structured_data.description: This study analyzes changes in global heat waves and their socioeconomic exposure in a warmer future. It defines heat waves as continuous high temperature processes exceeding absolute-relative combined high temperature thresholds for more than three consecutive days. The study uses historical reanalysis data and multi-scenario CMIP6 modeled data to develop a Global Heat Wave Toolbox (GHWT) to generate heat wave matrix from 1971 to 2100. It also employs population and GDP projections to estimate future socioeconomic exposure and risks. The study highlights areas of high heat wave activity (North Africa, North Australia, South Asia, Arabian Peninsula) and rapid heat wave growth (North Africa, Australia, Brazil), and projects significant population and economic exposure under SSP2 4.5 and SSP5 8.5 scenarios.

structured_data.name: CLASSnmat: monthly, global, gridded night marine air temperature data
structured_data.description: Climate Linked Atlantic Sector Science (CLASS)nmat is a global dataset of monthly mean night marine air temperature (NMAT) produced on a 5° latitude by 5° longitude regular grid. It covers the period 1880 to 2019. The data is based on ICOADS version 3.0.0 (1880-2014) and 3.0.2 (thereafter), adjusted for thermometer heights and quality-controlled. It includes absolute gridded data, anomaly values, and uncertainty estimates. Provided by Centre for Environmental Data Analysis (CEDA).

structured_data.name: ERA5 post-processed daily statistics on single levels from 1940 to present
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files (NetCDF in zip archive) via Copernicus Climate Change Service (CDS) web interface
structured_data.description: This dataset provides post-processed ERA5 hourly single-level data aggregated to daily time steps. ERA5 is the fifth generation ECMWF reanalysis for the global climate and weather. Data is available from 1940 to present and is updated daily with a delay of 6 days. Users can select daily aggregation statistics (mean, max, min, sum), sub-daily frequency sampling, and local time zone shifts.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: 0.25° x 0.25° (atmosphere), 0.5° x 0.5° (ocean waves) for reanalysis; 0.5° x 0.5° (atmosphere), 1° x 1° (ocean waves) for mean and members

structured_data.name: Spatial characterization of global heat waves using satellite-based land surface temperature
structured_data.method_of_access: View PDF, View Open Manuscript (via ScienceDirect)
structured_data.description: This study investigates global heat waves in 2018 using spatial datasets of land surface temperature (LST) derived from AQUA TIR sensors. A 15-year daily maximum LST dataset was used to identify hot days and heat wave events. The study highlights that remote sensing datasets are capable of providing continuous whole-Earth coverage of heat wave changes. The authors do not have permission to share data.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: 2018 (for heat wave analysis), 15-year daily maximum LST dataset used for baseline

structured_data.name: xclim.indices.biologically_effective_degree_days
structured_data.description: Calculates biologically effective growing degree days, adjusted for latitude and daily temperature range. Used as a heat-summation metric in viticulture agroclimatology. It takes daily minimum and maximum temperatures as input.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Daily data aggregated to seasonal/annual summaries

structured_data.name: Evaluating the ability of gridded climate datasets to capture temperature and precipitation trends and extremes
structured_data.description: This article evaluates the ability of four widely used gridded datasets (ERA5, ERA5-Land, MERRA-2, and PRISM) to capture extreme heat, extreme cold, and heavy precipitation events, as well as trends in annual maximum and minimum temperatures and total precipitation. It notes that gridded datasets generally captured extreme heat better than extreme cold or heavy precipitation.

structured_data.name: CHIRPS-GEFS
structured_data.description: CHIRPS-GEFS is a bias-corrected and downscaled version of NCEP Global Ensemble Forecast System (GEFS) version 12 precipitation forecasts, spatially compatible with CHIRPS data. It provides next 5-day to 15-day precipitation forecasts, updated daily, at a spatial resolution of ~5 km across the globe. It supports anticipating flood and drought hazards. Data available from January 2000 to December 2019 and October 2020 to present.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Daily (5-day, 10-day, 15-day forecasts), Dekadal, Pentadal; January 2000-December 2019 and October 2020-present

structured_data.name: CHIRTS-ERA5
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files (GeoTIFF, NetCDF), interactive web-based tool (Early Warning Explorer)
structured_data.description: CHIRTS-ERA5 is a quasi-global, high-resolution (0.05° x 0.05°, approx. 5km) dataset of daily maximum and minimum temperatures, heat index, and wet bulb globe temperature. Developed by the Climate Hazards Center (CHC), it combines satellite and station-based estimates from CHIRTS (1983-2016) with the regularly updated ERA5 reanalysis dataset, providing bias-corrected and downscaled temperature products. It is designed to address limitations in tracking extreme temperatures in data-sparse regions and is updated with a 5-day (Tmax/Tmin) or 6-day (HI/WBGT) lag.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: From 1983 onwards (CHIRTS-daily extends beyond 2016), daily data

structured_data.name: CRU TS v. 4.09
structured_data.method_of_access: Local Copy download, Climate Explorer web interface
structured_data.description: The current version of CRU TS, superseding v4.08, covers the period 1901-2024. It is a gridded time-series dataset covering all land areas (excluding Antarctica) at 0.5° resolution. Variables include pre, tmp, tmx, tmn, dtr, vap, cld, wet, frs, pet. Developed and maintained with support from NERC and US Department of Energy, with long-term support from NCAS.

structured_data.name: Berkeley Earth Global Temperature Data
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files (TXT, NetCDF) and request form for high-resolution gridded products
structured_data.description: Berkeley Earth provides high-resolution land and ocean time series data and gridded temperature data. Global datasets begin in 1850, with some land-only areas reported back to 1750. The newest generation of products are augmented by machine learning techniques to improve spatial resolution. The 1°x1° resolution products are no longer being updated as of Q2 2025, replaced by 0.25° x 0.25° products.

structured_data.name: Evaluation of Extreme Temperatures Over Australia in the Historical Simulations of CMIP5 and CMIP6 Models
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable PDF from Wiley Online Library
structured_data.description: This research article evaluates the historical simulations of extreme temperatures over 10 Australian regions using models from CMIP5 and CMIP6, with three models from CMIP6 including initial-condition large ensembles to estimate internal variability effects. It analyzes the models' abilities in simulating probability distributions of daily maximum and minimum temperatures (TX and TN) and the spatial patterns and temporal variations of extreme indices as defined by ETCCDI. The study uses observational datasets AWAP and BEST. Published on June 14, 2021.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Historical simulations (specific years not detailed, but refers to CMIP5 and CMIP6 historical periods)

structured_data.name: CHIRTS-daily
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files from CHC Website and Earth Engine Data Catalog
structured_data.description: CHIRTS-daily is a quasi-global, high-resolution (0.05° x 0.05°, approx. 5km) dataset of daily maximum and minimum temperatures developed by the Climate Hazards Center (CHC). It combines monthly CHIRTSmax data with ERA5 reanalysis to provide routinely updated data for monitoring temperature extremes. A rapid monitoring version (CHIRTS-ERA5) has a 6-day latency.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Daily, from Jan 1983 to Dec 2016 (data record mentioned), with a rapid monitoring version having 6-day latency.

structured_data.name: nClimGrid-Daily
structured_data.description: NCEI’s nClimGrid-Daily product contains gridded fields and area averages of daily maximum, minimum, and average temperatures (Tmax, Tmin, and Tavg) and daily precipitation amount (Prcp) for the Contiguous United States from January 1, 1951–present. The dataset is designed for climate monitoring and other applications that rely on placing event-specific meteorological patterns into a long-term historical context. Data are derived from morning and midnight observations from the Global Historical Climatology Network-daily (GHCNd) dataset.

structured_data.name: STAR-ESDM: A Generalizable Approach to Generating High-Resolution Climate Projections Through Signal Decomposition
structured_data.method_of_access: The document is a research article available online. The data generated by the STAR-ESDM model would likely be available through the authors or associated institutions, but no direct download link or API is provided in the content.
structured_data.data_format: Implied gridded data sets, point-based time series (NetCDF, GeoTIFF, CSV time series are common for such data, though not explicitly stated for STAR-ESDM output)
structured_data.description: The STAR-ESDM (Seasonal Trends and Analysis of Residuals empirical statistical downscaling model) is a computationally-efficient, flexible approach to generating high-resolution climate projections. It can be applied globally using predictands and predictors sourced from various data types (weather stations, gridded data sets, satellites, reanalysis, and global or regional climate models). It decomposes and smooths quasi-Gaussian time series into multi-decadal long-term means/trends, static and dynamic annual cycles, and probability distributions of daily variability. The model is capable of accurately reproducing projected changes for daily temperature and precipitation, with biases for extreme temperatures (<0.5°C) and extreme wet day precipitation (<5 mm/day) for most continental areas.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: High-resolution (specific resolution not given, but compared to coarse global climate model simulations, and capable of generating data at the spatial scale of the predictand time series, which can be 250m-1km for cities or 1-10km for regions for heatwave data).
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Continuous, high-resolution bias-corrected and downscaled time series (specific start/end years not given, but capable of future projections). Daily data is mentioned for temperature and precipitation.
structured_data.climate_scenario: Not explicitly stated, but the model is driven by 'coarse global climate model simulations', implying it can use various climate scenarios.

structured_data.name: The association between consecutive days’ heat wave and cardiovascular disease mortality in Beijing, China
structured_data.description: This research article investigates the effects of various combinations of differing heat wave temperatures and durations on the excess mortality risk (ER) posed by cardiovascular disease (CVD) in Beijing, China. It analyzes data using a generalized additive model (GAM) and finds that longer heat waves and higher temperatures significantly increase mortality risk, especially for elderly persons, females, and outdoor workers. The study was published on February 23, 2017.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: From 1961 to 2010 (for general heat wave trends in China); specific study period for Beijing not explicitly stated but implies historical data.

structured_data.name: Impact of Stratospheric Aerosol Geoengineering on Extreme Precipitation and Temperature Indices in West Africa Using GLENS Simulations
structured_data.method_of_access: Open Access Research Article (PDF available via URL)
structured_data.description: This research article investigates the impact of stratospheric aerosol geoengineering on extreme precipitation and temperature indices in West Africa, utilizing GLENS simulations. The study focuses on climate change impacts and potential mitigation strategies.

structured_data.name: Assessing the Global Climate in October 2022
structured_data.description: This monthly summary, developed by scientists at NOAA’s National Centers for Environmental Information, assesses the global climate in October 2022, highlighting temperature anomalies, sea ice extent, and precipitation patterns. It notes that October 2022 was the fourth-warmest October in the 143-year NOAA record, with land-only temperatures ranking second-warmest globally. It also provides regional temperature rankings and sea ice extent data for the Arctic and Antarctic.

structured_data.name: MODIS Land Surface Temperature and Emissivity (MOD11)
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files via DOI links (e.g., MOD11A1, MYD11A1)
structured_data.description: The MODIS Land Surface Temperature (LST) and Emissivity daily data are retrieved at 1km pixels by the generalized split-window algorithm and at 6km grids by the day/night algorithm. The product includes LSTs, quality assessment, observation time, view angles, and emissivities. It is provided by MODIS (NASA GSFC) and includes various products like daily, 8-day, and monthly LST/Emissivity data.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Daily, 8-Day, Monthly (from 2007 onward for C4.1 LST)

structured_data.name: Changes of extreme temperatures worldwide over recent decades
structured_data.description: This study quantifies changes of extreme temperatures worldwide over recent decades, identifying hotspots where the hottest temperatures are warming significantly faster than moderate temperatures. It highlights that climate models largely underestimate these trends, particularly positive trends exceeding 0.5 °C per decade. The study covers recent record-shattering heat events globally, including specific regional examples like the European, Russian, Siberian, North American Pacific Northwest, Amazon basin, and Southern African heatwaves.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Recent decades (since 1950 for some figures), with specific events up to 2023

structured_data.name: Spatiotemporal variation of intra-urban heat and heatwaves across Greater Sydney, Australia
structured_data.method_of_access: Data will be made available on request.
structured_data.description: This study analyzes the spatiotemporal variation of intra-urban heat and heatwaves, specifically in Greater Sydney, Australia. It compares canopy-layer air temperatures measured at 274 urban microsites during the summers of 2019 and 2020 with official weather station data. The study reveals that microsites recorded significantly more days of extreme heat than official stations, leading to novel 'heat risk' maps for local government areas. It highlights the underreporting of heat and its implications for preparedness in urban populations.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Summers of 2019 and 2020 (empirical data); 1859-2020 (historic air temperature measurements); until 2060 (trajectories of summer heat)

structured_data.name: Heatwaves intensification in Australia: A consistent trajectory across past, present and future
structured_data.description: This paper investigates changes in heatwave characteristics (peak temperature, number of events, frequency, duration) over a past 67-year period in Australia, projected changes for this century in Queensland, and avoided heatwave impacts of limiting global warming by 1.5 °C, 2.0 °C and 3.0 °C. The study reveals heatwaves have increased in intensity, frequency and duration across Australia over the past 67 years, with particular intensification in recent decades. Downscaled future climate projections for Queensland suggest further intensification. The findings are being used by health and emergency services to inform statewide policies.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Past 67-year period; Projections for current century

structured_data.name: Global future population exposure to heatwaves
structured_data.method_of_access: Data available in public repositories or upon request, with specific URLs provided for CMIP6, NASA SEDAC, PANGAEA, World Bank, and National Earth System Science Data Center.
structured_data.description: This study presents the first global fine-resolution projection of future changing urban population exposure to heatwaves by 2100 under four shared socioeconomic pathways (SSPs) considering urban expansion. It highlights rising global urban population exposure, particularly in temperate and tropical zones, and coastal/low-altitude cities. The study emphasizes the impact of climate effects and the interaction between climate and urbanization on exposure.

structured_data.name: ERA5
structured_data.description: ERA5 is the latest climate reanalysis produced by ECMWF, providing hourly data on many atmospheric, land-surface and sea-state parameters together with estimates of uncertainty. It is available from 1940 and continues to be extended forward in time, with daily updates being made available 5 days behind real time.

structured_data.name: Evaluation of the predictive skill for warm spells in Germany at seasonal scale
structured_data.description: This study evaluates the predictive skill of the downscaled German Climate Forecast System Version 2.1 (GCFS2.1) for warm spells in Germany on a seasonal scale for both warm (spring and summer) and cold seasons (autumn and winter). The analysis considers hindcast data from the 1991–2020 base period, statistically downscaled to a high spatial resolution over a region including Germany, along with five climate indices (Summer Days, Hot Days, Hot Spells Duration, Warm Days, and Warm Spells Duration).
structured_data.spatial_resolution: High spatial resolution over a region including Germany

structured_data.name: Changes in Global Heatwave Risk and Its Drivers Over One Century
structured_data.description: This research article, published in Earth's Future, investigates changes in global heatwave risk and its drivers over one century. It is an open-access publication.

structured_data.name: Cruel Summer (and Autumn): Humid Heat Trends, Extremes, and Mechanisms in the Southeast United States
structured_data.description: A research article focusing on humid heat trends, extremes, and mechanisms in the Southeast United States, published in the International Journal of Climatology. The article was first published on March 18, 2025. Funding was provided by NOAA Climate Program Office.

structured_data.name: Wet-Bulb Globe Temperature, Universal Thermal Climate Index, and Other Heat Metrics for US Counties, 2000–2020
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable PDF, database mentioned for US counties, R package for calculations
structured_data.description: A database of population-weighted, spatially explicit daily heat metrics – including WBGT, UTCI, heat index, dewpoint temperature, net effective temperature, and humidex – for counties in the conterminous United States derived from the ERA5-Land gridded data set. An R package is also provided to calculate these metrics.

structured_data.name: Allometric scaling of thermal infrared emitted from UK cities and its relation to urban form
structured_data.description: This study used MODIS satellite instrument images from 2000 to 2017 to examine seasonal (winter and summer) night-time clear-sky upwelling long-wave energy for 35 UK cities. It explores the relationship between urban population and total emitted energy, demonstrating a thermal 'economy (or parsimony) of scale' and suggesting similarities in energy budgets for urban areas of different sizes.

structured_data.name: Global heat stress on health, wildfires, and agricultural crops under different levels of climate warming
structured_data.granularity: Global, National (developing countries, Europe, US, Canada, Brazil, China, Australia, Russia, India)
structured_data.description: This study assesses the influences of 1.5 °C and 2.0 °C warmings on multiple sectors including health-related heat exposure, wildfire, and agricultural crops (maize, wheat, soybeans). It highlights that 0.5 °C less warming would significantly reduce exposure to these threats, especially in tropical regions and developing countries. The study uses global climate and impact models from the Inter-Sectoral Impact Model Intercomparison Project.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Global, with specific mentions of tropical regions and various countries.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Projections for 1.5 °C and 2.0 °C warming targets, extending to the end of the 21st century with high emissions.

structured_data.name: Global projections of heat stress at high temporal resolution using machine learning
structured_data.description: This study developed a machine learning approach to temporally downscale daily climate data to hourly Temperature Humidity Index (THI) values for dairy cattle. Utilizing historical ERA5 reanalysis data, an XGBoost model was trained to generate hourly THI datasets for 12 NEX-GDDP-CMIP6 climate models under two emission scenarios (SSP2-4.5 and SSP5-8.5) extending to the end of the century. The dataset aims to provide accurate quantification of heat stress in dairy cattle to improve predictions and management strategies.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Historical ERA5 reanalysis data; projections to the end of the century

structured_data.name: Global climate-related predictors at kilometer resolution for the past and future (CHELSA-BIOCLIM+ dataset)
structured_data.description: A dataset of climate-related variables at unprecedented spatiotemporal detail for environmental and ecological analyses. It includes downscaled time series of near-surface relative humidity (hurs), cloud area fraction (clt), and near-surface wind speed (sfcWind), combined with mechanistically downscaled temperature, precipitation, and solar radiation to calculate vapor pressure deficit (vpd), surface downwelling shortwave radiation (rsds), potential evapotranspiration (pet), climate moisture index (cmi), and site water balance (swb) at monthly and 30 arcsec resolution globally from 1980-2018. It also estimates climatological normals of frost change frequency (fcf), snow cover days (scd), potential net primary productivity (npp), growing degree days (gdd), and growing season characteristics for 1981–2010, 2011–2040, 2041–2070, and 2071–2100, considering SSP126, SSP370, SSP585 scenarios and five Earth system models. Provided by Philipp Brun et al.

structured_data.name: A Review of Recent Advances in Research on Extreme Heat Events
structured_data.description: This is a review article published on August 3, 2016, discussing recent advances in research on extreme heat events. It covers changes in characteristics like magnitude, frequency, and duration, their sensitivity to global warming, and attribution to anthropogenic warming. It also explores process-based studies focusing on land-atmosphere interactions and atmospheric circulation, and risks associated with compound extreme events.

structured_data.name: Estimation and uncertainty analysis of impacts of future heat waves on mortality in the eastern United States
structured_data.granularity: County-level for the eastern United States
structured_data.description: This study estimates future heat wave mortality in the eastern United States (approximately 1,700 counties) under two Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) for 2057–2059. It investigates sources of uncertainty in these estimates, projecting 200–7,807 deaths/year (mean 2,379 deaths/year) attributable to heat waves. The study uses dynamically downscaled hourly temperature projections and apportions uncertainty using a variance-decomposition method. The major sources of uncertainty were relative risk estimates, RCP scenarios, and heat wave definitions. The study was conducted by Wu J, Zhou Y, Gao Y, Fu JS, Johnson BA, Huang C, Kim YM, Liu Y and published in Environ Health Perspect in 2014.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: County-level for the eastern United States

structured_data.name: Web-based Heat Health Monitoring: Leveraging Global Gridded Vulnerability and Exposure Data for an AI-Enabled Decision Support System (DSS)
structured_data.method_of_access: Web-based DSS (Decision Support System) with AI-enabled features
structured_data.description: This paper presents an innovative web-based Heat Health Monitoring and Decision Support System (DSS) model that integrates geospatial data on vulnerability and exposure. It combines the Universal Thermal Climate Index (UTCI) with Gridded Population of the World and Global Gridded Relative Deprivation Index datasets to calculate exposure and vulnerability. The system provides insights into heat health risks, enabling decision-makers to take informed actions and protect vulnerable communities by classifying areas based on heat stress levels (No thermal stress, Moderate, Strong, Very strong, Extreme heat stress) and estimating population exposure. The AI-enabled system will suggest actions and health advisories.

The model projects increases in the number of hot days, especially over plain areas under RCP8.5 in the far future.

structured_data.name: Heat Index Probability Forecasts
structured_data.description: These forecast products display the probability of the daily minimum, maximum, and mean heat index exceeding specific thresholds. Color filled displays of probabilities and expected heat index values are based on Weather Prediction Center (WPC) or Model Output Statistics (MOS) maximum and minimum temperature and dew point temperature forecast grids. The MOS is used for projection day 3; the WPC forecasts are used for projection days 4 through 7. The probabilities have a normal distribution about the WPC or MOS forecast heat indexes with spatially varying standard deviations representing forecast uncertainty derived from an ensemble, which includes the NCEP Global Forecast System (GFS) high resolution model and the NCEP Global Ensemble Forecast System (GEFS). The calculations are done at regularly spaced grid points approximately 20 km apart across the continental United States (CONUS).

structured_data.description: This paper assesses the potential of using the Universal Thermal Climate Index (UTCI) for forecasting thermal health hazards on a global scale. It provides probabilistic UTCI forecasts, demonstrating their superiority over deterministic forecasts for lead times up to 10 days. The paper also highlights the utility of these forecasts using the example of the 2010 heat wave in Russia.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Up to 10-day lead times (probabilistic forecasts), with an example of the 2010 heat wave in Russia.

structured_data.name: High-Resolution Dynamical Downscaling Ensemble Projections of Future Extreme Temperature Distributions for the United States
structured_data.description: This study examines projections of extreme temperatures over the continental United States (CONUS) for the 21st century using an ensemble of high spatial resolution dynamically downscaled model simulations. It analyzes probability density functions of daily maximum/minimum temperatures over seven climatologically cohesive regions of the CONUS and investigates the impacts of different boundary conditions and future GHG concentrations on extreme events like heat waves and days with temperature higher than 95°F. The study projects increased intensity of extreme warm temperatures and decreased frequency of extreme cold temperatures, with 5-day heat waves projected to occur at least 5–10 times per year in most CONUS and ≥95°F days increasing by 1–2 months by the end of the century under a “business-as-usual” scenario.
structured_data.climate_scenario: Two different future greenhouse gas (GHG) concentration trajectories, including a “business-as-usual” scenario

structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query, HDF file download implied
structured_data.description: The VNP21C2 dataset is an 8-day composite Land Surface Temperature and Emissivity (LST&E) product at 0.05 degree (~5,600 meter) resolution, provided by NASA/NOAA Suomi NPP VIIRS. It combines daily VNP21A1D and VNP21A1N products using a simple-averaging method for climate simulation models. The dataset contains 25 Science Datasets (SDS) including LST, quality control, view zenith angle, and time of observation for both day and night, along with emissivity for bands M14, M15, and M16. It covers from 2012-01-17 to Present, with an 8-day temporal resolution. Known issues include extreme high temperature outliers over desert regions due to undetected cloud and dust.

structured_data.name: Projections of heatwave-attributable mortality under climate change and future population scenarios in China
structured_data.description: This study projects heatwave-attributable deaths in China under different emission and population scenarios, using a regional climate model driven by three CMIP5 GCM models and future gridded population data based on Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2. It analyzes factors driving changes in heatwave-related deaths and compares death burdens under the 1.5°C target. The study finds continuous increases in heatwave-related deaths to mid-century even under low emission scenarios, with significant health benefits from achieving the 1.5°C goal.

structured_data.name: Anthropogenic climate change exacerbates the risk of successive flood-heat extremes: Multi-model global projections based on the Inter-Sectoral Impact Model Intercomparison Project
structured_data.description: This study presents a global-scale evaluation of projected changes and uncertainties in successive flood-heat extreme (SFHE) characteristics (frequency, intensity, duration, land exposure) and population exposure under RCP2.6 and RCP6.0 scenarios. It uses multi-model ensembles (five global water models forced by four global climate models) within the Inter-Sectoral Impact Model Intercomparison Project 2b framework. The study projects increased SFHE frequency globally, particularly in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau and tropical regions, and increased population exposure in South and East Asia and Central Africa.

structured_data.name: Rapid rises in the magnitude and risk of extreme regional heat wave events in China
structured_data.method_of_access: View PDF, Download full issue, View Open Manuscript
structured_data.description: This study revealed an approximate doubling in both the frequency and the magnitude of regional heat wave events observed over 1960–2018 in China. The identified top three regional heat wave events occurred in the summers of 2013, 2017, and 2003, respectively. Fine-resolution multimodel climate projections suggest that China will experience regional heat wave events with magnitude exceeding the 2013 heat event on a regular basis by 2030 under a business-as-usual scenario (RCP8.5). Compared to a 2 °C warming level, 1.5 °C warming could halve the expected occurrence of future severe regional heat wave events with magnitude similar to or slightly greater than the record-breaking one in 2013.
